paragraphs.text:
%md

# Music Recommendator

msg.data: Music Recommendator

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Preparing the Data

Let's start by downloading the data :

msg.data:
Preparing the Data

Let’s start by downloading the data :

paragraphs.text:
%sh
cd /data
if [[ ! -d profiledata_06-May-2005 ]]
then
    if [[ ! -f profiledata_06-May-2005.tar.xz ]]
    then 
        echo "Downloading profiledata_06-May-2005.tar.xz"
        curl --silent https://drive.switch.ch/index.php/s/gK6l44wTWixlaeC/download -o profiledata_06-May-2005.tar.xz
        echo "Extracting to profiledata_06-May-2005"
        tar xfv profiledata_06-May-2005.tar.xz
    fi
fi
ls -lhF profiledata_06-May-2005

msg.data:
total 464M
-rw-r--r-- 1 1000 1000 2.8M May  6  2005 artist_alias.txt
-rw-r--r-- 1 1000 1000  54M May  6  2005 artist_data.txt
-rw-r--r-- 1 1000 1000 1.3K May 10  2005 README.txt
-rw-r--r-- 1 1000 1000 407M May  5  2005 user_artist_data.txt

paragraphs.text:
%md
Next, read the user artist data and transform it in a Dataframe with two columns "user" and "artist" :

msg.data: Next, read the user artist data and transform it in a Dataframe with two columns “user” and “artist” :

paragraphs.text:
%spark
val rawUserArtistData = spark.read.textFile("/data/profiledata_06-May-2005/user_artist_data.txt")
rawUserArtistData.take(5).foreach(println)

val userArtistDF = rawUserArtistData.map { line => 
    val Array(user, artist, _*) = line.split(' ')
    (user.toInt, artist.toInt)
}.toDF("user", "artist")
userArtistDF.printSchema
userArtistDF.agg(min("user"), max("user"), min("artist"), max("artist")).show()

paragraphs.text:
%md
Next, read the raw artist data and transform it in a Dataframe with two columns "id" and "name" :

msg.data: Next, read the raw artist data and transform it in a Dataframe with two columns “id” and “name” :

rawArtistData: org.apache.spark.sql.Dataset[String] = [value: string]
artistByID: org.apache.spark.sql.DataFrame = [id: int, name: string]

paragraphs.text:
%md
Next, read the alias artist data and transform it in a Map with artist id for the key and alias for value :

msg.data: Next, read the alias artist data and transform it in a Map with artist id for the key and alias for value :

paragraphs.text:
%spark
val rawArtistAlias = spark.read.textFile("/data/profiledata_06-May-2005/artist_alias.txt")
val artistAlias = rawArtistAlias.flatMap { line =>
    val Array(artist, alias) = line.split('\t')
    if (artist.isEmpty) None
    else Some((artist.toInt, alias.toInt))
}.collect().toMap

artistByID.filter($"id" isin (1208690, 1003926)).show()

%spark

import org.apache.spark.sql._
import org.apache.spark.broadcast._

// Cleaning data in bonus

/**
 * Convert count musics to approximatively years of listening
 */
def countToYear(count: Int): Boolean = {
    val avgSongMinutesLength = 4.0
    avgSongMinutesLength * count.toDouble / 60.0 / 24.0 / 365.0 < 2
}
 
def buildCounts(rawUserArtistData: Dataset[String], bArtistAlias: Broadcast[Map[Int,Int]]): DataFrame = {
    val unknownId = artistByID.filter($"name" === "[unknown]").select($"id").head.getInt(0)
    val userArtistCleanedDF = userArtistDF.filter($"artist" !== unknownId)
    
    rawUserArtistData.map { line =>
        val Array(userID, artistID, count) = line.split(' ').map(_.toInt)
        val finalArtistID = bArtistAlias.value.getOrElse(artistID, artistID)
        (userID, finalArtistID, count)
    }.toDF("user", "artist", "count").filter($"artist" !== unknownId)
}
val bArtistAlias = spark.sparkContext.broadcast(artistAlias)
val trainData = buildCounts(rawUserArtistData, bArtistAlias).filter($"count" < 400000)
trainData.orderBy(desc("count")).show
trainData.cache()

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Statistics

msg.data: Statistics

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Describe statistics

msg.data: Describe statistics

paragraphs.text:
%spark
val userSummary = trainData.describe("user")
userSummary.show

val artistSummary = trainData.describe("artist")
artistSummary.show

val countSummary = trainData.describe("count")
countSummary.show

%md
## Data fusion
Compute a Dataframe with user id, artist id, artist name and count for later uses.

msg.data:
Data fusion

Compute a Dataframe with user id, artist id, artist name and count for later uses.

paragraphs.text:
%spark
val userArtistNamesCountDF = 
    trainData
    .join(artistByID, artistByID("id") === trainData("artist"))
    .select("user", "artist", "name", "count")
userArtistNamesCountDF.cache
userArtistNamesCountDF.show

%md
## Around users

msg.data: Around users

paragraphs.text:
%md
Get users number

msg.data: Get users number

paragraphs.text:
%spark
val distinctUsersNumber = userArtistNamesCountDF.select("user").distinct.count
println(distinctUsersNumber)

msg.data:
148077
distinctUsersNumber: Long = 148077

paragraphs.text:
%md
Let's see the listen's total per user and sort it by the higher.

msg.data: Let’s see the listen’s total per user and sort it by the higher.

paragraphs.text:
%spark
val userListenArtists = userArtistNamesCountDF.groupBy("user").sum("count").select($"user", $"sum(count)" as "total")
userListenArtists.cache

val mostUserListenArtists = userListenArtists.sort(desc("total"))
mostUserListenArtists.show

z.show()

The first user made almost 400'000 plays !

paragraphs.text:
%md
Now let's see how many different artists the users listen in average.

msg.data: Now let’s see how many different artists the users listen in average.

paragraphs.text:
%spark
val artistsPerUser = userDifferentArtists.groupBy("user").count.sort(desc("count"))
artistsPerUser.cache

println(artistsPerUser.count)
artistsPerUser.describe("count").show

%md
Users listen to 162 artists in average.

paragraphs.text:
%md
Get least listened artists.

%spark
val leastListenedArtistsDF = listenedArtistsDF.sort("total")
leastListenedArtistsDF.show

leastListenedArtistsDF: org.apache.spark.sql.Dataset[org.apache.spark.sql.Row] = [name: string, total: bigint]

paragraphs.text:
%md
There is not much infos, a lot of artists are at one listen.
Show how many artist are listened less or equal than 10 times, and the frequence for 1 to ten.

msg.data:
There is not much infos, a lot of artists are at one listen.
Show how many artist are listened less or equal than 10 times, and the frequence for 1 to ten.

paragraphs.text:
%spark
val lessThanTenTimesListenedArtistsDF = listenedArtistsDF.filter("total <= 10")
val count = lessThanTenTimesListenedArtistsDF.count
val ratio = count.toDouble / distinctArtistsNumber.toDouble

msg.data:
lessThanTenTimesListenedArtistsDF: org.apache.spark.sql.Dataset[org.apache.spark.sql.Row] = [name: string, total: bigint]
count: Long = 1161120
ratio: Double = 0.7470896434222049

paragraphs.text:
%md
More than one million are listened less or equal than ten times, it's about 75% of all artists.
Now let's see the distribution :

msg.data:
More than one million are listened less or equal than ten times, it’s about 75% of all artists.
Now let’s see the distribution :

paragraphs.text:
%spark
val freqOneToTenDF = lessThanTenTimesListenedArtistsDF.groupBy("total").count.sort("total")
freqOneToTenDF.show
z.show(freqOneToTenDF)

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

msg.data: freqOneToTenDF: org.apache.spark.sql.Dataset[org.apache.spark.sql.Row] = [total: bigint, count: bigint]

paragraphs.text:
%md
The most artists are listened only one time.

Now compute mean and median of total count listened artists.

msg.data:
The most artists are listened only one time.

Now compute mean and median of total count listened artists.

paragraphs.text:
%spark
val mean = listenedArtistsDF.agg(avg("total")).head.getDouble(0)

val median = listenedArtistsDF.stat.approxQuantile("total", Array(0.5), 0.01)(0)

msg.data:
mean: Double = 238.32715067690853
median: Double = 3.0

paragraphs.text:
%md
We can see that half of the artists were listened to less than three times, which can be considered a discovery or even a mistake.

msg.data: We can see that half of the artists were listened to less than three times, which can be considered a discovery or even a mistake.

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Around mispelled artists names

Let's see which artists are the most misspelled. First compute a Map with the correct artist id as key and the list of "bad" ids associated as value.

msg.data:
Around mispelled artists names

Let’s see which artists are the most misspelled. First compute a Map with the correct artist id as key and the list of “bad” ids associated as value.

paragraphs.text:
%spark
val artistsWithMostWrongAlias = aliasToListWrongNames.map { case (k,v) => (k, v.length) }.toList.toDF("artist", "count")
artistsWithMostWrongAlias.describe("count").show
artistsWithMostWrongAlias.sort(desc("count")).show
val ratio = artistsWithMostWrongAlias.count.toDouble / distinctArtistsNumber.toDouble

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.text:
%md
We can see there is 22'478 artists names (~ 1.5% of total artists number) misspelled and the worst has it 1204 times ! Let's see who this artist is.

msg.data: We can see there is 22’478 artists names (~ 1.5% of total artists number) misspelled and the worst has it 1204 times ! Let’s see who this artist is.

paragraphs.text:
%spark
artistByID.select("name").filter("id == 1000024").show

%md
Oh no ! It's Metallica ! How is that even possible ? Let's see the 1204 errors.

msg.data: Oh no ! It’s Metallica ! How is that even possible ? Let’s see the 1204 errors.

paragraphs.text:
%spark
val aliasIdsToMetallica = aliasToListWrongNames.getOrElse(1000024, Array()).toList.toDF("id")
val aliasNamesToMetallica = aliasIdsToMetallica.join(artistByID, artistByID("id") === aliasIdsToMetallica("id"))
aliasNamesToMetallica.show(false)

paragraphs.text:
%md
Before run the portion of code above, we think that the name "Metallica" was misspelled. However, as we can see, it's more a name with some details or additions than just bad spelling.

msg.data: Before run the portion of code above, we think that the name “Metallica” was misspelled. However, as we can see, it’s more a name with some details or additions than just bad spelling.

paragraphs.text:
%md
# A look with GraphX

Now, we put this data in a graph with [GraphX](https://spark.apache.org/docs/latest/graphx-programming-guide.html).
Our nodes will be the users and the artists and edges the relation listens count between user and artist.
Because users id and artists id can be equal, we need to generate a unique id for each nodes, call it VertexId.
From userArtistNamesCountDF, we can extract two RDDs, users and artists, and zip it with the unique id (an "auto increment" id).

msg.data:
A look with GraphX

Now, we put this data in a graph with GraphX.
Our nodes will be the users and the artists and edges the relation listens count between user and artist.
Because users id and artists id can be equal, we need to generate a unique id for each nodes, call it VertexId.
From userArtistNamesCountDF, we can extract two RDDs, users and artists, and zip it with the unique id (an “auto increment” id).

paragraphs.text:
%spark

import org.apache.spark.graphx._
import org.apache.spark.rdd._

val subDF = userArtistNamesCountDF.limit(1000000)

val users = subDF
    .select("user") // select only users
    .distinct // remove duplicates
    .rdd // convert to rdd (for graph creation needs)
    .map(_.getInt(0)) // convert it to a list of INTs
    .zipWithIndex // add the "auto increment" unique id, or VertexId
    .map(_.swap) // swap the tuple, because the graph need a RDD[(VertexId, T)]
    
val lastUserId = users.count

val artists = subDF
    .select("artist") // select only artists
    .distinct // remove duplicates
    .rdd // convert to rdd (for graph creation needs)
    .map(_.getInt(0)) // convert it to a list of INTs
    .zipWithIndex // add the "auto increment" unique id, or VertexId
    .map(_.swap) // swap the tuple, because the graph need a RDD[(VertexId, T)]
    .map { case (vertexId, id) => (vertexId + lastUserId, id) } // to maintain unique VertexId, add users.count to each artist VertexId

users.cache
artists.cache

val nodes: RDD[(VertexId, Int)] = users.union(artists)
//nodes.collect.foreach(println)
//val nodesDF = nodes.toDF("vertexId", "id")
//nodesDF.show

val edges: RDD[Edge[Int]] = subDF.map { line =>
    val userId = line.getInt(0)
    val artistId = line.getInt(1)
    val userVertexId = users.filter{ case (vertexId, id) => id == userId }.first._1
    val artistVertexId = artists.filter{ case (vertexId, id) => id == artistId }.first._1
    val count = line.getInt(2)
    Edge(userVertexId, artistVertexId, count)
}.rdd

val graph = Graph(nodes, edges)
graph.cache

%md
## Building a First Model

msg.data: Building a First Model

paragraphs.text:
%spark
import org.apache.spark.ml.recommendation._
import scala.util.Random

val model = new ALS().
    setSeed(Random.nextLong()).
    setImplicitPrefs(true).
    setRank(10).
    setRegParam(0.01).
    setAlpha(1.0).
    setMaxIter(5).
    setUserCol("user").
    setItemCol("artist").
    setRatingCol("count").
    setPredictionCol("prediction").
    fit(trainData)

%md
## Spot Checking Recommendations

msg.data: Spot Checking Recommendations

paragraphs.text:
%spark
val userID = 1059637
val existingArtistIDs = trainData.filter($"user" === userID).select("artist").as[Int].collect()
artistByID.filter($"id" isin (existingArtistIDs:_*)).show()

%spark
def makeRecommendations(model: ALSModel, userID: Int, howMany: Int): DataFrame = {
    val toRecommend = model.itemFactors.select($"id".as("artist")).withColumn("user", lit(userID))
    model.transform(toRecommend).select("artist", "prediction").orderBy($"prediction".desc).limit(howMany)
}

val topRecommendations = makeRecommendations(model, userID, 5)
topRecommendations.show()
